Posts.Content: robinjs19 wrote: Hi everybody, I was just diagnosed March 2 and have surgery scheduled on the 10th. I have 4 or more tumors in my right breast (3 were biopsied).  All three are IDC (I think that's the right acronym -- invasive ductal).    All tests show that the left breast is fine. I have extremely dense breasts and these tumors were very hard to find.   I had a clear mammo and ultrasound last June.  If I hadn't found a lump, I don't believe the screening would have. My doctor is encouraging a bilateral.  I'm also waiting for the results of the Brach (sp?) test... if that's positive then this is a no brainer.  (I am Ashkenazi, and my mother also had breast cancer.) But, if it's negative.   ?  Should I still have the bilateral?    All thoughts are most, most welcome.   thank you! Robin Dx 3/2/2009, IDC, 2cm, Stage IIA, Grade 2, 1/8 nodes, ER+/PR+ Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Uni- or Bi-? robinjs19 robinjs19

Posts.Content: Mar 14, 2009 10:46PM robinjs19 wrote: Hi all, Thanks again for all the thoughts and input.  I'm about 99% sure I will do the bilateral.  I am scheduled for bil at this point, but my surgeon assures me that I can change my mind practically as I'm wheeled into the operating room.  I did have an MRI, which gave the left breast a clean bill of health.  I'm curious how much the risk of getting cancer in that breast has increased simply because I have cancer in the right.  I have no other risk factors, so I'm just wondering. The most compelling reason to go ahead with the bil is the dense breast issue and the need for  MRIs to be sure nothings happening in there. I'm not a worrier, so peace of mind just isn't a big issue for me -- but my family is another story.  My husband, daughters, parents, siblings all really want me to have the bil and never have to worry about it.  I keep thinking that the decision to remove the breast is irreversible.   The decision to keep it can be changed at any time.   Of course that means going through surgery and recovery again. I have over 2 weeks to get to think about this and get completely comfortable with my decision.  Thanks again for all the support Robin

Posts.Content: robinjs19 wrote: I had a right Mx and removal of 8 nodes on 3/30 and came out with a well expanded expander -- 400 ccs  (with Alloderm).  So I have this big swollen thing that resembles a breast only in relative size and position.   It has two lumps -- the top half is where the expander is under the muscle, the bottom half is where it is under the Alloderm.  The top half is tight and swollen and painful.  The bottom is loose.   The top contricts and gets really painful, then loosens up.   I'm taking valium at night to relax the muscles which helps.  I don't get how this will all eventually come together into a real breast -- but I told my PS that I knew if it ended up like this he wouldn't still be in business, so I have faith! Has anyone had this particular situation?? Dx 3/2/2009, IDC, 2cm, Stage IIA, Grade 2, 1/8 nodes, ER+/PR+ Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Did anyone have a "two-part" boob? robinjs19 robinjs19

Posts.Content: Apr 16, 2009 02:22AM robinjs19 wrote: Alloderm is artifical tissue they can use to create a "sac" to hold the bottom of the implant.   So instead of putting the implant behind the muscle and slowly filling over time, they fill it almost full, put about half under the muscle, and create a sac with alloderm to hold the bottom.  I didn't do a whole lot of research beforehand on this and it doesn't appear that many people on the forum had the procedure done that way.    So, right now, as I said, the top is under the muscle and is really tight and painful (that's lessening now), and the bottom is loose... and it looks like a two part boob.   I'm sure it will look great in the end, but it would be nice to talk to someone who's gone through it... thanks, Robin
